subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}

The traditional interpretation is that the three horizontal strokes represent Heaven, Man and Earth. The vertical stroke is the king, the one who connects them together. Older representation of the character shows a man like {{zh-l|*大}} or {{zh-l|*天}} above a horizontal stroke.

The modern interpretation is that the character is a {{liushu|p|nocap=y}} of either an axe or a crown, one of two symbols of the king's power. A ceremonial axe was kept near the throne, and was used for performing rituals in ancient China.

Compare the unrelated {{zh-l|*玉|jade}} and {{zh-l|*主|master}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
Unknown.

Speculations exist about [[王]]'s connection to {{och-l|尪}} "lame" ({{w|Zuozhuan|Zuo}}) and {{och-l|狂}} "mad", based on theories about the connection between ancient Chinese kingship and shamanism (Chen 1936, Chang 1983, Keightley 1995).

{{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} provides two etymologies:
*From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*d-baŋ||strength, power}}, cognate with {{cog|bo|tr=dbang|t=strength, power}}, {{cog|my|tr=aŋ|t=strength, maturity}}, and {{cog|ths|tr=⁴paŋ|t=strength}}. However, Schuessler notes the mismatch between OC '''*w-''' vs. Tibetan '''*b-''' (unless '''*dw-''' became '''db-'''; for possible *'''b-'''~*'''w-''' variation see [[花]]).
*Of possible {{w|Proto-Austroasiatic language|Austroasiatic}} origin. Compare {{cog|mkh-pro|*waŋ; *waaŋ||to go round (v.), enclosure (n.)}}, whence {{cog|km|វាំង||palace}} and {{cog|mkh-okm|hlūṅa||[[title]] of [[mandarinate]]}}), for in a {{w|Chinese bronze inscriptions|bronze inscription}} [[王]] refers to a place, not the {{w|Zhou dynasty|Zhou}} king (Shaughnessy, 1991). The semantic shift from "palace" to "king" parallels {{w|Egyptian language|Egyptian}} {{m|egy|pr ꜥꜣ|t=[[pharaoh]]|lit=palace, from {{m|egy|pr|t=house}} + {{m|egy|ꜥꜣ|t=great, big}}}}
[[王]]'s connection to {{och-l|[[皇]]}} "sovereign", as proposed by Boodberg (1980), is unclear.
